bestBHT.bht: By both, half-belief was strengthened into faith in Him: but in each case it is of a different kind. The inner kernel of the history is the elevation of a weak and mere wonder-seeking faith into a deep conviction of the personal power and love of our Lord. The external point brought out in the commendation there, 'I have not seen such faith, no, not in Israel,' is not only different from, but stands in absolute contrast with, the depreciating charge here, 'Except ye see signs and wonders, ye will not believe.'

Henry Alford: By both, half-belief was strengthened into faith in Him: but in each case it is of a different kind.
The inner kernel of the history is, in our case here,—the elevation of a weak and mere wonder-seeking faith into a deep conviction of the personal power and love of our Lord.

And the external point brought out in the commendation there, 'I have not seen such faith, no, not in Israel,' is not only different from, but stands in absolute contrast with, the depreciating charge here, 'Except ye see signs and wonders, ye will not believe.'
Philip Schaff: The two points upon which our attention is fixed seem to be (1) that this miracle was wrought in Galilee; (2) that it was a second miracle there.
The first of these points receives importance from the fact that the 'sign' now related was done after Jesus had left 'His own country,' rejected by 'His own' to be accepted by Galileans.
It is not necessary to discuss the question whether this miracle is identical with that related in Matthew 8:5-13; Luke 7:2-10. We may wonder that such a question was ever raised.
Archibald T. Robertson: This again a second sign did Jesus having come out of Judea into Galilee.
The first one was also in Cana (John 2:1), but many were wrought in Jerusalem also (John 2:23).
John Gill: This [is] again the second miracle [that] Jesus did....
when he was come out of Judea into Galilee; this was the first he wrought, after his coming out of Judea into Galilee.
was the second that he wrought in Cana of Galilee; see John 2:11.

bhtAttempts.bht: By both, half-belief was strengthened into faith in Him: but in each case it is of a different kind. The inner kernel of the history is the elevation of a weak and mere wonder-seeking faith into a deep conviction of the personal power and love of our Lord. The external point brought out in the commendation there, 'I have not seen such faith, no, not in Israel,' is not only different from, but stands in absolute contrast with, the depreciating charge here, 'Except ye see signs and wonders, ye will not believe.' This again a second sign did Jesus having come out of Judea into Galilee.

By both, half-belief was strengthened into faith in Him: but in each case it is of a different kind. The inner kernel of the history is the elevation of a weak and mere wonder-seeking faith into a deep conviction of the personal power and love of our Lord. The external point brought out in the commendation there, 'I have not seen such faith, no, not in Israel,' is not only different from, but stands in absolute contrast with, the depreciating charge here, 'Except ye see signs and wonders, ye will not believe.'

In John 4:54, we see the transformation of a weak and wonder-seeking faith into a deep conviction of the power and love of Jesus. Despite the contrast between the commendation of such unwavering faith and the charge to believe only when seeing signs and wonders, Jesus performs a second sign in Galilee. This miracle signifies His acceptance by the Galileans after being rejected by His own people. It is a testament to the different kinds of faith and the transformative power of encountering Jesus.

By both, half-belief was strengthened into faith in Him: but in each case, it is of a different kind. The inner kernel of the history is the elevation of a weak and mere wonder-seeking faith into a deep conviction of the personal power and love of our Lord. The external point brought out in the commendation is not only different from, but stands in absolute contrast with the depreciating charge here. This again a second sign did Jesus perform, underscoring the significance of this miracle in Galilee.

The transformation of a weak and wonder-seeking faith into a deep conviction of the power and love of our Lord is evident in John 4:54. Despite the contrast between the commendation and the charge to believe only when seeing signs and wonders, Jesus performs a second sign in Galilee. This miracle signifies His acceptance by the Galileans after being rejected, emphasizing the different kinds of faith and the transformative encounter with Jesus.
